items.title: Can I change the word euros for soles (peruvian currency) or simple not show it?
items.body:
### Expected Behaviour

`num2words(1670.60, to='currency', lang='es')`

Should return;

`mil seiscientos setenta soles con sesenta céntimos`

or not show the type of currency at all.

`mil seiscientos setenta con sesenta céntimos`

### Actual Behaviour

`mil seiscientos setenta euros con sesenta céntimos`

### Steps to reproduce

```
from num2words import num2words
num2words(1670.60, to='currency', lang='es')
```

items.title: Decimal numbers correction for Spanish
items.body:
### Expected Behaviour

Decimal digits are written according to the number of significant digits, not each number individually. The current operation is correct with respect to the tests defined, but incorrect from the point of view of writing in Spanish language.

(2.14, 'dos punto catorce')

### Actual Behaviour

(2.14, 'dos punto uno cuatro')

### Steps to reproduce
Run:
* $num2words 2.14 -l es
* dos punto uno cuatro

items.title: Num2words Doesn't change the currency based on country name
items.body:
Why the currency still in Euro currency even i have changed the language?
Is there anything that I need to change to use this library? Thanks. 

### Expected Behaviour

>>> num2words(25502.51, to='currency', lang='en')
'twenty-five thousand, five hundred and two dollars, fifty-one cents'
>>> num2words(25502.51, to='currency', lang='en_GB')
'twenty-five thousand, five hundred and two pounds, fifty-one pence'

### Actual Behaviour
>>> num2words(2550251,to='currency',lang='en')
'twenty-five thousand, five hundred and two euro, fifty-one cents'
>>> num2words(2550251,to='currency',lang='en_GB')
'twenty-five thousand, five hundred and two euro, fifty-one cents'

items.title: Romanian language issues:
items.body:
Some issues:
```
num2words(22000, lang='ro')
'douăzeci și doi mie'
```
should be
```douăzeci și două mii```

For currency, i know the convention is „una” instead of „o”. That's what it is written on the banknotes, „UNA SUTĂ”. 

I'm currently adjusting the result with:
`.replace('o mie', 'una mie').replace('o sută', 'una sută').replace('doi mie','două mii').replace(' ', '')`
(also removing the spaces for financial documents)

_Originally posted by @silvium in https://github.com/savoirfairelinux/num2words/pull/215#issuecomment-499239834_

items.title: en_US currency print euro instead of dollar
items.body:
### Expected Behaviour
>>> num2words (1000, to='currency', lang='en_US')
'one thousand dollars'


### Actual Behaviour
>>> num2words (1000, to='currency', lang='en_US')
'ten euro, zero cents'


### Steps to reproduce

* step 1  pip install --user num2words
* step 2 from num2words import num2words

items.body:

Negative amounts should work for LT and LV.

### Actual Behaviour

It gives this error:

```python
In [18]: num2words.num2words(-5000, lang='lt')
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-18-32c571144a4c> in <module>()
----> 1 num2words.num2words(-5000, lang='lt')

/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/num2words/__init__.py in num2words(number, ordinal, lang, to, **kwargs)
    100         raise NotImplementedError()
    101 
--> 102     return getattr(converter, 'to_{}'.format(to))(number, **kwargs)

/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/num2words/lang_LT.py in to_cardinal(self, number)
    107             )
    108         else:
--> 109             return self._int2word(int(n))
    110 
    111     def to_ordinal(self, number):

/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/num2words/lang_LT.py in _int2word(self, n)
    122         for x in chunks:
    123             i -= 1
--> 124             n1, n2, n3 = get_digits(x)
    125 
    126             if n3 > 0:

/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/num2words/utils.py in get_digits(n)
     14 
     15 def get_digits(n):
---> 16     a = [int(x) for x in reversed(list(('%03d' % n)[-3:]))]
     17     return a

/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/num2words/utils.py in <listcomp>(.0)
     14 
     15 def get_digits(n):
---> 16     a = [int(x) for x in reversed(list(('%03d' % n)[-3:]))]
     17     return a
```


### Steps to reproduce

Try to convert any negative amount for `lt` or `lv`.

items.title: Integer input, as a string, gives floating point output
items.body:
### Expected Behaviour

```
assert num2words('18') == 'eighteen
assert num2words(18) == 'eighteen'
```

### Actual Behaviour

```python
assert num2words('18') == 'eighteen point zero'
assert num2words(18) == 'eighteen'
```

### Steps to reproduce

```
$ python --version
Python 3.6.6 :: Anaconda, Inc.
$ pip install -y num2words
$ python -c 'from num2words import num2words; print(num2words("18")); print(num2words(18))'
```

items.title: french currency decimal bug
items.body:
### Expected Behaviour

>>> num2words(1.5, lang='fr', to='currency')
'un euro et **cinquante** centimes'

idem:
>>> num2words(1.50, lang='fr', to='currency')
'un euro et **cinquante** centimes'

### Actual Behaviour

>>> num2words(1.5, lang='fr', to='currency')
'un euro et **cinq** centimes'

>>> num2words(1.50, lang='fr', to='currency')
'un euro et **cinq** centimes'

so .5 in numbers returns .05 in letters, .50 in numbers also returns .05 in letters.

### Steps to reproduce

num2words(**number**, lang='fr', to='currency')
with number being any single digit decimal number or double digit ending with a zero

```
ثاني
ثالث
رابع
خامس
سادس
سابع
ثامن
تاسع
عاشر
حادي عشر

خامس عشر
سادس عشر
سابع عشر
ثامن عشر
تاسع عشر
```

```
أول

تاسع

*خمسة عشر*
*ستة عشر*
*سبعة عشر*

*تسعة عشر*
```

Type the code I pasted

items.title: "Ordinal" vs "Cardinal" on pypi
items.body:
The *usage* section of the [Pypi project page](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/num2words) lists the result of `num2words(42, to='cardinal')` as the ordinal result

### Expected Behaviour

Text should read:

```
>>> num2words(42, to='cardinal')
forty-two
```

or

```
>>> num2words(42, to='ordinal')
forty-second
```


### Actual Behaviour

Text reads

```
>>> num2words(42, to='cardinal')
forty-second
```

items.title: to_currency with cents false seem to be broken
items.body:
`to_currency` form that takes `currency` as argument with `cents=False` seem to produce unexpected results when there is not enough precision available.

For instance `num2words(Decimal('38.4'), lang='lv', to='currency', seperator=' un', cents=False, currency='EUR)` results in `Trīsdesmit astoņi euro un 04 centi`.

Is this expected behaviour? All converters that support this form seem to be affected.

`left, right = n.split('.')` seems to be too naive for right part since it doesn't respect position.

items.title: unicode problem with python2.7, lang="de"
items.body:
Hello,  thanks for this module!

I came across a unicode problem.  You can see this works with python3:

```bash
$ python3 -c "import num2words; print(num2words.num2words(0.5, lang='de'))"
null Komma fünf null
```

but fails with python 2.7:

```bash
$ python2.7 -c "import num2words; print(num2words.num2words(0.5, lang='de'))"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/num2words/__init__.py", line 50, in num2words
    return converter.to_cardinal(number)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/num2words/base.py", line 93, in to_cardinal
    return self.to_cardinal_float(value)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/num2words/base.py", line 127, in to_cardinal_float
    out.append(str(self.to_cardinal(curr)))
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xfc' in position 1: ordinal not in range(128)
```

The problem being the call to `str()` which in python3 returns a unicode string, but in 2.7 `str()` can only return ASCII bytes.  (In 2.7 `unicode()` would need to be called instead of `str()` to get a unicode string)

items.title: Ein vs. Eins in German
items.body:
Hi, 
Currently num2words(1, lang='de') gives "eins" which is correct in certain contexts (e.g. if one refers to the digit one or  "Page 1" --> "Seite Eins") but wrong in other cases (if it is followed by a noun, e.g. "1 Meter'" => Ein Meter", "Eins Meter" would be wrong). I'm not sure how this can be handled properly, maybe by an additional flag so that the user can decide weather "eins" or "ein" should be returned? If this is to much work I would suggest changing it to "ein", because from my feeling this variant is used more often. But of course this depends on the context, maybe other German speaker can comment on this as well.

items.title: "one hundred, ninety-eight" vs. "one hundred ninety-nine"  vs. "one hundred and ninety-eight"
items.body:
Comparing the outputs of Taro Ogawa's original library (namely num2word_EN.to_card) and yours, I found some recurring discrepancies:

```
one hundred and ninety-eight
one hundred, ninety-eight (the "and" is replaced by a comma)

one hundred and ninety-nine
one hundred ninety-nine (the "and" is suppressed)

two hundred and ninety-eight
two hundred, ninety-eight

two hundred and ninety-nine
two hundred, ninety-nine

...
```

Taro Ogawa's gives the expected result (21124) on the 17th problem of the Projet Euler: http://projecteuler.net/problem=17. Yours give 21070. Using `lang="en"` or `lang="en_GB"` makes no difference.

Bugs in tanslation from 30 to 40 in spanish
items.body:
In [23]: for n in range(29, 41):
        print num2words.num2words(n, lang='es')
   ....:  
vientinueve
vientinueve y uno
vientinueve y dos
vientinueve y tres
vientinueve y cuatro
vientinueve y cinco
vientinueve y seis
vientinueve y siete
vientinueve y ocho
vientinueve y nueve
vientinueve y diez
cuarenta

items.title: Wrong float interpretation
items.body:
I'm running the example as:

```
num2words(11)
u'eleven'
```

And then:

```
num2words(11.10)
u'eleven point zero nine'
```

Somehow there is a rounding somewhere doing it wrong.
